title: Practice – Using Prepositions with the Ablative (Rest & Relationship)
goals: Chant and translate Ablative prepositional phrases
Compare with Accusative motion phrases for contrast
Use verbs of rest (est, sedet, manet, habitat)
Reflect on peace as right placement – Pax

steps.speak: Salve! Welcome to Week 15 Day 2. Today we’ll rest in the grammar we discovered yesterday!
Chant with me: in hortō (in the garden), sub arbore (under the tree), cum amīcō (with a friend), ē templō (out of the temple), dē monte (down from the mountain).
Notice the endings –ā, –ō. These show rest and relationship — no motion!
Act it out! Sit quietly as you say in hortō. Raise your hand gently for sub arbore. Join hands for cum amīcō.
Now compare: in hortō (in the garden) vs. in hortum (into the garden). Which one moves?
Correct — in hortum moves (Accusative); in hortō rests (Ablative).
Say and translate together: Puella sedet in hortō – The girl sits in the garden.
Puer est sub arbore – The boy is under the tree.
Faith phrase: Cum Deō ambulāmus – We walk with God. Even when we move, we move within His peace.
Virtue reflection: Peace is not stillness without purpose — it’s resting where God places you.
Quick chant review: –ā, –ō — rest and peace! Motion gone, quiet release!
Optime! Tomorrow we’ll build full sentences that show rest and relationship.
